{| class="infobox" style="width: 300px;" |- | {| style="background: red; white-space: nowrap;" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 |- | colspan=2 |[[File:PIA22566-VoyagerProgram&Heliosphere-Chart-20181003.jpg|300px|]] |- |[[File:Heliosphere-washbasin.svg|x115px|Sink analogy]][[File:Solar wind at Voyager 1 cut out.png|x115px|]] |- | colspan=2 | [[File:PIA17046 - Voyager 1 Goes Interstellar.jpg|300px|]] |} |- | * '''Top''': Diagram of the heliosphere as it travels through the [[interstellar medium]]:{{Ordered list|type=lower-alpha|item_style=margin-left:-22px;<!---|''Termination shock'': the [[solar wind]] collides for the first time with the interstellar medium, slows down and changes direction.--->|''Heliosheath'': the outer region of the heliosphere; the solar wind is compressed and turbulent|''Heliopause'': the boundary between solar wind and interstellar wind where they are in equilibrium.<!---|''[[#Bow shock|Bow shock]] (?)'': the shock wave caused by the heliosphere in the direction it travels. (Probably does not exist.)--->}} * '''Middle''': water running into a sink as an analogy for the heliosphere and its different zones (left) and [[Voyager 1|Voyager]] measuring a drop of the solar wind's high-energy particles at the termination shock (right) * '''Bottom''': Logarithmic scale of the Solar System and Voyager's position |}
The '''heliosphere''' is the bubble-like [[outer space#Interplanetary space|region of space]] dominated by the [[Sun]], which extends far beyond the orbit of [[Pluto]]. [[Plasma (physics)|Plasma]] "blown" out from the Sun, known as the [[solar wind]], creates and maintains this bubble against the outside [[pressure]] of the [[interstellar medium]], the hydrogen and helium gas that permeates the [[Milky Way|Milky Way Galaxy]]. The solar wind flows outward from the Sun until encountering the '''termination shock''', where motion slows abruptly. The [[Voyager program|Voyager spacecraft]] have explored the outer reaches of the heliosphere, passing through the shock and entering the '''heliosheath''', a transitional region which is in turn bounded by the outermost edge of the heliosphere, called the '''heliopause'''. The shape of the heliosphere is controlled by the interstellar medium through which it is traveling, as well as the Sun and is not perfectly spherical.<ref name="nasa-voyager-proves" /> The limited data available and unexplored nature of these structures have resulted in many theories.<ref name="scientificamerican-voyager" /> The word "heliosphere" is said to have been coined by [[Alexander J. Dessler]], who is credited with first use of the word in the scientific literature.<ref name="dessler-revgeophys" />
On September 12, 2013, [[NASA]] announced that [[Voyager 1]] left the heliopause on August 25, 2012, when it measured a sudden increase in plasma density of about forty times.<ref name="voyager-historic" /> Because the heliopause marks [[Solar System#Boundaries|one boundary]] between the Sun's solar wind and the rest of the galaxy, a spacecraft such as Voyager 1 which has departed the heliosphere, can be said to have reached [[Outer space#Interstellar space|interstellar space]].
== Summary == [[File:IBEX all sky map.jpg|thumb|right|[[Energetic neutral atoms]] map by [[IBEX]]. Credit: NASA / [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] Scientific Visualization Studio.]] [[File:Teilchendichte Voyagersonden.jpg|thumb|500px|Graph of detections by Voyager 1 & 2]]
The idea of Heliosphere is an area of the influence of the Sun, and a major component is magnetic field lines and the solar wind; three major aspects to its edge are the termination shock, the heliosheath, and the heliopause. Five spacecraft have returned much of the data about its furthest reaches including Pioneer 10 (1972-1997; data to 67 AU), Pioneer 11 (1973-1995;44 AU), Voyager 1 and 2 (launched 1977, ongoing), and New Horizons (Launched 2006). A type of particle called an ENA has also been observed to have been produced from its edges. Near the Sun, there is a host of spacecraft that observe the Sun and interplanetary space, and one of the latest to explore nearer to the Sun than ever before is the [[Parker Solar Probe]] launched in 2018. Solar observations, such by Solar eclipses that allow observation of the Corona and various types of space observatories also provide data on the Sun and its influences. The study of other Stars can also allow insights indirectly.
Except for [[Magnetosphere|regions]] near obstacles such as [[planet]]s or [[Comet#Coma and tail|comets]], the heliosphere is dominated by material emanating from the Sun, although [[cosmic rays]], [[Energetic neutral atoms|fast-moving neutral atoms]], and [[cosmic dust]] can penetrate the heliosphere from the outside. Originating at the extremely hot surface of the [[corona]], solar wind particles reach [[escape velocity]], streaming outwards at 300 to 800 km/s (671 thousand to 1.79 million mph or 1 to 2.9 million km/h).<ref>[http://solarscience.msfc.nasa.gov/SolarWind.shtml The Solar Wind]</ref> As it begins to interact with the [[interstellar medium]], its velocity slows to a stop. The point where the solar wind becomes slower than the speed of sound is called the [[Heliosphere#Termination shock|termination shock]]; the solar wind continues to slow as it passes through the [[heliosheath]] leading to a boundary called the [[Heliopause (astronomy)#Heliopause|heliopause]], where the interstellar medium and solar wind pressures balance. The termination shock was traversed by [[Voyager 1]] in 2004,<ref name=voyager/> and [[Voyager 2]] in 2007.<ref name="nasa-voyager-proves" />
It was thought that beyond the heliopause there was a [[bow shock]], but data from [[Interstellar Boundary Explorer]] suggested the velocity of the Sun through the interstellar medium is too low for it to form.<ref name="No-Bow-Shock" /> It may be a more gentle "bow wave".<ref name=zank>{{cite journal|title=Heliospheric Structure: The Bow Wave and the Hydrogen Wall|first1=G. P.|last1=Zank|first2=J.|last2=Heerikhuisen|first3=B. E.|last3=Wood|first4=N. V.|last4=Pogorelov|first5=E.|last5=Zirnstein|first6=D. J.|last6=McComas|date=1 January 2013|journal=Astrophysical Journal|volume=763|issue=1|pages=20|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/763/1/20|doi-access=free|bibcode = 2013ApJ...763...20Z }}</ref> Voyager data led to a new theory that the heliosheath has "magnetic bubbles" and a stagnation zone.<ref name=stag/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/voyager/multimedia/20110609_briefing_materials.html |title=NASA - Voyager - Conditions At Edge Of Solar System|publisher=NASA|date=9 June 2011|accessdate=2018-09-05}}</ref>
The 'stagnation region' within the heliosheath, starting around {{convert|113|au|abbr=on|lk=in}}, was detected by [[Voyager 1]] in 2010.<ref name=stag>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/voyager/voyager20111205.html|title=NASA's Voyager Hits New Region at Solar System Edge|first=Holly|last=Zell|date=5 December 2011|publisher=NASA|accessdate=2018-09-05}}</ref> There the solar wind velocity drops to zero, the magnetic field intensity doubles and high-energy electrons from the galaxy increase 100-fold.<ref name=stag/> Starting in May 2012 at {{convert|120|au|abbr=on}},<!-- Voyager 1 was 119.9 AU in March 2012, traveling at 3.6 AU per year--> [[Voyager 1]] detected a sudden increase in cosmic rays, an apparent signature of approach to the heliopause.<ref name=rays>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/voyager/voyager20120614.html|title=NASA - Data From NASA's Voyager 1 Point to Interstellar Future|date=14 June 2012|publisher=NASA|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref> In December 2012 NASA announced that in late August 2012 Voyager 1, at about {{convert|122|au|abbr=on}} from the Sun, entered a new region they called the "magnetic highway", an area still under the influence of the Sun but with some dramatic differences.<ref name=voyager>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2012-381|title=NASA Voyager 1 Encounters New Region in Deep Space|publisher=}}</ref> In the summer of 2013, NASA announced that Voyager 1 had reached [[interstellar space]] as of August 25, 2012.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/voyager/voyager20130912.html#.UjJLPZKR86s|title=NASA Spacecraft Embarks on Historic Journey Into Interstellar Space|first=Tony|last=Greicius|date=5 May 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]] and [[Interstellar Boundary Explorer|IBEX]] data challenged the "heliotail" theory in 2009.<ref name="Cassini-shape-solar-system" /><ref name="IBEX-2009" /> In July 2013, IBEX results revealed a 4-lobed tail on the Solar System's heliosphere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/nasa-s-ibex-provides-first-view-of-the-solar-system-s-tail/|title=IBEX Provides First View Of the Solar System's Tail|first=Holly|last=Zell|date=6 March 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Pioneer 10]] was launched in March 1972, and within 10 hours passed by the Moon; over the next 35 years or so the mission would be the first out laying out many firsts of discoveries about the nature of heliosphere as well as Jupiter's impact on it.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2017/07/pioneer-10-first-probe-inner-precursor-juno/|title=Pioneer 10: first probe to leave the inner solar system & precursor to Juno – NASASpaceFlight.com|website=www.nasaspaceflight.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> Pioneer 10 was the first spacecraft to detect sodium and aluminum ions in the Solar Wind, as well as helium in the inner solar system.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2017/07/pioneer-10-first-probe-inner-precursor-juno/|title=Pioneer 10: first probe to leave the inner solar system & precursor to Juno – NASASpaceFlight.com|website=www.nasaspaceflight.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> In November of 1972, Pioneer 10 encountered Jupiter's enormous (compared to Earth) magnetosphere, and would pass in and out of it and heliosphere 17 times charting its interaction with the Solar Wind.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2017/07/pioneer-10-first-probe-inner-precursor-juno/|title=Pioneer 10: first probe to leave the inner solar system & precursor to Juno – NASASpaceFlight.com|website=www.nasaspaceflight.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> Pioneer 10 returned scientific data until March 1997, including data on the Solar wind out to about 67 AU at that time.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/missions/archive/pioneer10-11.html|title=NASA - Pioneer-10 and Pioneer-11|website=www.nasa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> It was also contacted in 2003, when it was a distance of 7.6 billion miles from Earth (82 AU), but no instrument data about the Solar Wind was returned then.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/releases/2003/03_25HQ.html|title=NASA - PIONEER 10 SPACECRAFT SENDS LAST SIGNAL|website=www.nasa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/p/pioneer10-11.html|title=Pioneer 10-11|website=www.astronautix.com|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref>
Voyager 1, surpassed the radial distance from Sun of Pioneer 10 at 69.4 AU on 17 February 1998, because it was traveling faster gaining about 1.02 AU per year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/missions/archive/pioneer.html|title=The Pioneer Missions|last=Administrator|first=NASA Content|date=2015-03-03|work=NASA|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en}}</ref> Pioneer 11, launched a year after Pioneer 10, took similar data as Pioneer out to 44.7 AU in 1995 when that mission was concluded.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/p/pioneer10-11.html|title=Pioneer 10-11|website=www.astronautix.com|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> Pioneer 11 had a similar instrument suite as 10, but also had a Flux-Gate Magnetometer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/missions/archive/pioneer.html|title=The Pioneer Missions|last=Administrator|first=NASA Content|date=2015-03-03|work=NASA|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en}}</ref> Pioneer and Voyager spacecraft were on different trajectories, and thus recorded data on the heliosphere in different overall directions away from the Sun.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/p/pioneer10-11.html|title=Pioneer 10-11|website=www.astronautix.com|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> Pioneer and Voyager data helped corroborate the detection of a hydrogen wall.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Thomas.|first=Hall, Doyle|date=1992|title=Ultraviolet resonance radiation and the structure of the heliosphere.|url=https://repository.arizona.edu/handle/10150/186043?show=full|language=en}}</ref>
Voyager 1 and 2 were launched in 1977 and operated continuously to at least the late 2010s, and encountered various aspects of the Heliosphere past Pluto and Neptune.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/voyager-2-approaches-interstellar-space/|title=Voyager 2 Approaches Interstellar Space - Sky & Telescope|date=2018-10-10|work=Sky & Telescope|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2012 Voyager 1 is thought to have pass through the Heliopause, and in 2018 there is some indications Voyager 2 may be experiencing the same threshold.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/voyager-2-approaches-interstellar-space/|title=Voyager 2 Approaches Interstellar Space - Sky & Telescope|date=2018-10-10|work=Sky & Telescope|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Solar wind == {{main|Solar wind|Interplanetary medium}} [[File:The Sun as seen in January 1st 2015.jpg|thumb|Earth's Sun as seen at a wavelength of 19.3 nanometers ([[ultraviolet]])]]
The solar wind consists of particles ([[ion]]ized atoms from the solar [[corona]]) and fields (in particular, [[magnetic field]]s).{{clarify|date=June 2015}} Because the Sun [[rotation|rotate]]s once approximately every 25 days, the magnetic field transported by the [[solar wind]] gets wrapped into a spiral. Variations in the Sun's magnetic field are carried outward by the solar wind and can produce [[Geomagnetic storm|magnetic storm]]s in the Earth's own [[magnetosphere]].{{clarify|date=June 2015}}
== Structure == [[File:Heliospheric-current-sheet.gif|thumb|200px|left|The heliospheric current sheet out to the orbit of Jupiter]]
=== Heliospheric current sheet === {{main|Heliospheric current sheet}}
The [[heliospheric current sheet]] is a ripple in the heliosphere created by the rotating magnetic field of the Sun. Extending throughout the heliosphere, it is considered the largest structure in the Solar System and is said to resemble a "ballerina's skirt".<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Mursula, K. |author2=Hiltula, T. |bibcode=2003GeoRL..30.2135M |title=Bashful ballerina: Southward shifted heliospheric current sheet |date=2003 |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=30 |issue=22 |page=2135 |doi=10.1029/2003GL018201}}</ref>
=== Outer structure ===
The outer structure of the heliosphere is determined by the interactions between the solar wind and the winds of interstellar space. The solar wind streams away from the Sun in all directions at speeds of several hundred km/s in the Earth's vicinity. At some distance from the Sun, well beyond the orbit of [[Neptune]], this supersonic wind must slow down to meet the gases in the [[interstellar medium]]. This takes place in several stages: * The solar wind is traveling at [[supersonic]] speeds within the Solar System. At the termination shock, a standing [[shock wave]], the solar wind falls below the speed of sound and becomes [[Speed of sound|subsonic]]. * It was previously thought that, once subsonic, the solar wind would be shaped by the ambient flow of the interstellar medium, forming blunt nose on one side and comet-like heliotail behind, a region called the heliosheath. However, observations in 2009 showed that this model is incorrect.<ref name="Cassini-shape-solar-system" /><ref name="IBEX-2009" /> As of 2011, it is thought to be filled with a magnetic bubble "foam".<ref name=surprise/> * The outer surface of the heliosheath, where the heliosphere meets the interstellar medium, is called the '''heliopause'''. This is the edge of the entire heliosphere. Observations in 2009 led to changes to this model.<ref name="Cassini-shape-solar-system" /><ref name="IBEX-2009" /> * In theory, the heliopause causes turbulence in the interstellar medium as the sun orbits the [[Galactic Center]]. Outside the heliopause, would be a turbulent region caused by the pressure of the advancing heliopause against the [[interstellar medium]]. However, the velocity of Solar wind relative to the interstellar medium is probably too low for a bow shock.<ref name="No-Bow-Shock" />
=== Termination shock === [[File:Heliosphere-washbasin.svg|thumb|A termination shock in a sink basin]]
The termination shock is the point in the heliosphere where the solar wind slows down to [[Speed of sound#Speed of sound in plasma|subsonic]] speed (relative to the Sun) because of interactions with the local [[interstellar medium]]. This causes [[compression (physical)|compression]], heating, and a change in the [[magnetic field]]. In the [[Solar System]] the termination shock is believed to be 75 to 90 [[astronomical unit]]s<ref name="apod-heliosphere" /> from the Sun. In 2004, [[Voyager 1]] crossed the [[Sun]]'s termination shock followed by [[Voyager 2]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2007/voyager-1210.html |title=MIT instrument finds surprises at solar system's edge |publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology |date=2007-12-10 |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | first=Bill | last=Steigerwald | date=May 24, 2005 | url=http://www.nasa.gov/vision/universe/solarsystem/voyager_agu.html | title=Voyager Enters Solar System's Final Frontier | publisher=American Astronomical Society | accessdate= 2007-05-25 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date = December 10, 2007 |url = http://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/news/voyager_squashed.html |title = Voyager 2 Proves Solar System Is Squashed |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 2007-05-25 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071213180613/http://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/news/voyager_squashed.html |archivedate = December 13, 2007 |df = }}</ref><ref name=Voy1-term2004>{{cite web |date=1 June 2005 |title=Voyager Termination Shock |publisher=Department of Physics and Astronomy (University of Iowa) |author=Donald A. Gurnett |url=http://www-pw.physics.uiowa.edu/space-audio/voyager/termination-shock/ |accessdate=2008-02-06}}</ref><ref name=Voy1-term2005>{{cite web |date=25 May 2005 |title=Voyager 1 reaches the edge of the solar system |publisher=New Scientist |author=Celeste Biever |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg18625015.000-voyager-1-reaches-the-edge-of-the-solar-system.html |accessdate=2008-02-06}}</ref><ref name="voyager-historic" /><ref name=Voy2-term2007>{{cite web |date=10 December 2007 |title=Voyager 2 probe reaches solar system boundary |publisher=New Scientist |author=David Shiga |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn13029-voyager-2-probe-reaches-solar-system-boundary.html |accessdate=2008-02-06}}</ref><ref name="nasa-voyager-proves" />
The shock arises because solar wind particles are emitted from the Sun at about 400 km/s, while the speed of sound (in the interstellar medium) is about 100 km/s. (The exact speed depends on the density, which fluctuates considerably.) The interstellar medium, although very low in density, nonetheless has a constant pressure associated with it; the pressure from the solar wind decreases with the square of the distance from the Sun. As one moves far enough away from the Sun, the pressure of the solar wind drops to where it can no longer maintain supersonic flow against the pressure of the interstellar medium, at which point the solar wind slows to below its speed of sound, causing a [[shock wave]]. Further from the Sun, the termination shock is followed by the heliopause, where the two pressures become equal and solar wind particles are stopped by the interstellar medium.
Other termination shocks can be seen in terrestrial systems; perhaps the easiest may be seen by simply running a water [[Tap (valve)|tap]] into a [[sink]] creating a [[hydraulic jump]]. Upon hitting the floor of the sink, the flowing water spreads out at a speed that is higher than the local [[Phase velocity|wave speed]], forming a disk of shallow, rapidly diverging flow (analogous to the tenuous, supersonic solar wind). Around the periphery of the disk, a shock front or wall of water forms; outside the shock front, the water moves slower than the local wave speed (analogous to the subsonic interstellar medium).
Evidence presented at a meeting of the [[American Geophysical Union]] in May 2005 by [[Ed Stone]] suggests that the ''[[Voyager 1]]'' spacecraft passed the termination shock in December 2004, when it was about 94 AU from the Sun, by virtue of the change in magnetic readings taken from the craft. In contrast, ''[[Voyager 2]]'' began detecting returning particles when it was only 76 AU from the Sun, in May 2006. This implies that the heliosphere may be irregularly shaped, bulging outwards in the Sun's northern hemisphere and pushed inward in the south.<ref name="voyager_II_cnn">{{cite news | first=Ker | last=Than | title=Voyager II detects solar system's edge | publisher=CNN | date=May 24, 2006 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/TECH/space/05/23/voyager.2/index.html | accessdate=2007-05-25 }}</ref>
=== Heliosheath === [[File:Transitional regions.jpg|thumb|This picture about the heliosphere was released on June 28, 2013 and incorporates results from the Voyager spacecraft.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/news/transitional_regions.html|title=Voyager - The Interstellar Mission|first=|last=JPL.NASA.GOV|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708092850/http://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/news/transitional_regions.html|archivedate=2013-07-08|df=}}</ref>]]
The heliosheath is the region of the heliosphere beyond the termination shock. Here the wind is slowed, compressed and made turbulent by its interaction with the interstellar medium. Its distance from the [[Sun]] is approximately 80 to 100 [[astronomical unit]]s (AU) at its closest point.
A proposed model hypothesizes that the heliosheath is shaped like the [[coma (cometary)|coma]] of a comet, and trails several times that distance in the direction opposite to the Sun's path through space. At its windward side, its thickness is estimated to be between 10 and 100 AU.<ref name="Brandt-2007" /> However, observations in 2009 showed that model may be incorrect.<ref name="Cassini-shape-solar-system" /><ref name="IBEX-2009" />
The ''[[Voyager 1]]'' and ''[[Voyager 2]]'' spacecraft have studied the heliosheath. In late 2010, ''Voyager 1'' reached a region of the heliosheath where the solar wind's velocity had dropped to zero.<ref name = "Amos">{{cite news| first=Jonathan | last=Amos | date=December 14, 2010 | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-11988466 | title=Voyager near Solar Systems edge | accessdate = 2010-12-10 | work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name="Space.Com">{{cite web|title=NASA's Voyager 1 Spacecraft Nearing Edge of the Solar System|website=Space.Com |date = 2010-12-13|url=http://www.space.com/scienceastronomy/nasa-voyager-1-leaving-solar-system-101213.html|accessdate=2010-12-15}}</ref><ref name="Brumfiel">{{Cite journal | last = Brumfiel | first = G. | title = Voyager at the edge: spacecraft finds unexpected calm at the boundary of Sun's bubble | journal = Nature | date = 2011-06-15 | doi = 10.1038/news.2011.370 }}</ref><ref name = "Krimigis">{{Cite journal | last = Krimigis | first = S. M. | authorlink = | last2 = Roelof | first2 = E. C. | authorlink2 = | last3 = Decker | first3 = R. B. | authorlink3 = | last4 = Hill | first4 = M. E. | authorlink4 = | title = Zero outward flow velocity for plasma in a heliosheath transition layer | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume = 474 | issue = 7351| pages = 359–361 | date = 2011-06-16 | language = | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v474/n7351/abs/nature10115.html | jstor = | issn = | doi = 10.1038/nature10115 | pmid = 21677754 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate = 2011-06-20|bibcode = 2011Natur.474..359K }}</ref> In 2011, astronomers announced that the ''Voyagers'' had determined that the heliosheath is not smooth, but is filled with 100 million-mile-wide bubbles created by the impact of the solar wind and the interstellar medium.<ref name = "Cook">{{cite web|last = Cook | first = J.-R. | title=NASA Probes Suggest Magnetic Bubbles Reside At Solar System Edge| url= http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2011/jun/HQ_11-174_Voyager_Update.html|publisher=NASA/JPL|date=2011-06-09|accessdate=2011-06-10}}</ref><ref name="Rayl">{{cite web |last = Rayl |first = A. j. s. |title = Voyager Discovers Possible Sea of Huge, Turbulent, Magnetic Bubbles at Solar System Edge |publisher = [[The Planetary Society]] |date = 2011-06-12 |url = http://www.planetary.org/news/2011/0612_Voyager_Discovers_Possible_Sea_of_Huge.html |doi = |accessdate = 2011-06-13 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110616125502/http://www.planetary.org/news/2011/0612_Voyager_Discovers_Possible_Sea_of_Huge.html |archivedate = 2011-06-16 |df = }}</ref> ''Voyager 1'' and ''2'' began detecting evidence for the bubbles in 2007 and 2008, respectively.<ref name = "Rayl"/> The probably sausage-shaped bubbles are formed by [[magnetic reconnection]] between oppositely oriented sectors of the [[solar magnetic field]] as the solar wind slows down.<ref name = "Rayl"/> They probably represent self-contained structures that have detached from the [[interplanetary magnetic field]].<ref name = "Cook"/><ref name = "Rayl"/>
=== Heliopause ===
The heliopause is the theoretical boundary where the [[Sun]]'s [[solar wind]] is stopped by the [[interstellar medium]]; where the solar wind's strength is no longer great enough to push back the [[stellar wind]]s of the surrounding stars. This is the boundary where the interstellar medium and solar wind pressures balance. The crossing of the heliopause should be signaled by a sharp drop in the temperature of charged particles,<ref name = "Space.Com"/> a change in the direction of the magnetic field, and an increase in the number of galactic cosmic rays.<ref name=rays/> In May 2012, ''[[Voyager 1]]'' detected a rapid increase in such cosmic rays (a 9% increase in a month, following a more gradual increase of 25% from Jan. 2009 to Jan. 2012), suggesting it was approaching the heliopause.<ref name=rays/> In September of 2013, NASA announced that Voyager 1 had crossed the heliopause as of August 25, 2012.<ref name=":2" /> This was at a distance of 121 AU (18 billion km) from the Sun.<ref name="Cowen2013">{{Cite journal | last1 = Cowen | first1 = R. | doi = 10.1038/nature.2013.13735 | title = Voyager 1 has reached interstellar space | journal = Nature | year = 2013}}</ref> Contrary to predictions, data from Voyager 1 indicates the magnetic field of the galaxy is aligned with the solar magnetic field.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vergano|first1=Dan|title=Voyager 1 Leaves Solar System, NASA Confirms|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/13/130911-voyager-interstellar-solar-system-nasa-science-space/|publisher=National Geographic|accessdate=9 February 2015|date=2013-09-14}}</ref> {{wideimage|Ibexheliosphererevised.jpg|775px|"..solar wind and the interstellar medium interact to create a region known as the inner heliosheath, bounded on the inside by the termination shock, and on the outside by the heliopause."-NASA<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2016/nasa-s-ibex-observations-pin-down-interstellar-magnetic-field|title=NASA's IBEX Observations Pin Down Interstellar Magnetic Field|first=Rob|last=Garner|date=26 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref>}}
=== Heliotail ===
The heliotail is the tail of the heliosphere, and thus the solar system's tail. It can be compared to the tail of a comet (however, a comet's tail does not stretch behind it as it moves; it is always pointing away from the Sun). The tail is a region where the Sun's solar wind slows down and ultimately escapes the heliosphere, slowly evaporating because of charge exchange.<ref>[http://www.astrobio.net/pressrelease/5553/the-unexpected-structure-of-the-heliotail "The Unexpected Structure of the Heliotail"], ''Astrobiology''. July 12, 2013</ref> The shape of the heliotail (newly found by NASA's Interstellar Boundary Explorer - IBEX), is that of a four-leaf clover.<ref name="ReferenceA">Cole, Steve. [http://www.nasa.gov/press/2013/july/nasa-satellite-provides-first-view-of-the-solar-systems-tail/#.UmxeevmkrJa "NASA Satellite Provides First View of the Solar System's Tail"] NASA News Release 12-211, July 10, 2013</ref> The particles in the tail do not shine, therefore it cannot be seen with conventional optical instruments. IBEX made the first observations of the heliotail by measuring the energy of "energetic neutral atoms", neutral particles created by collisions in the solar system's boundary zone.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
The tail has been shown to contain fast and slow particles; the slow particles are on the side and the fast particles are encompassed in the center. The shape of the tail can be linked to the sun sending out fast solar winds near its poles and slow solar wind near its equator more recently. The clover-shaped tail moves further away from the sun, which makes the charged particles begin to morph into a new orientation.
== Additional Heliosphere structures == [[File:PIA12375.jpg|thumb|The bubble-like heliosphere moving through the interstellar medium]] [[File:Solarmap.png|thumb|Solar map with the location of the hypothetical hydrogen wall and bow shock]] [[File:STEREO ENAs HI.jpg|thumb|ENA detection is more concentrated one direction.<reF>[https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/stereo/news/invisible_frontier.html]</ref>]]
The heliopause is the final known boundary between the heliosphere and the interstellar space that is filled with material, especially plasma, not from our own star, the Sun, but from other stars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/voyager/glossary.html#.UjjiKW1pP3Uis|title=Voyager Glossary|first=Tony|last=Greicius|date=11 September 2013|publisher=}}</ref> Even so, just outside the heliosphere (i.e. the "solar bubble") there is a transitional region, as detected by Voyager 1.<ref name=interstellar>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/voyager/voyager20130912.html|title=NASA Spacecraft Embarks on Historic Journey Into Interstellar Space|first=Tony|last=Greicius|date=5 May 2015|publisher=}}</ref> Just as some interstellar pressure was detected as early as 2004, some of the Sun's material seeps into the interstellar medium.<ref name=interstellar/> The heliosphere is thought to reside in the [[Local Interstellar Cloud]] inside the [[Local Bubble]], which is a region in the [[Orion Arm]] of the [[Milky Way Galaxy]].
Outside the heliosphere there is a forty-fold increase in plasma density.<ref name=interstellar/> There is also a radical reduction in the detection of certain types of particles from the Sun, and a large increase in Galactic cosmic rays.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2013-278|title=How Do We Know When Voyager Reaches Interstellar Space?|publisher=}}</ref>
The flow of the [[interstellar medium]] (ISM) into the heliosphere has been measured by at least 11 different spacecraft as of 2013.<ref name=flow>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/goddard/interstellar-wind-changed-direction-over-40-years/|title=Interstellar Wind Changed Direction Over 40 Years|first=Holly|last=Zell|date=6 March 2015|publisher=}}</ref> By 2013, it was suspected that the direction of the flow had changed over time.<ref name=flow/> The flow, coming from Earth's perspective from the constellation Scorpius, has probably changed direction by several degrees since the 1970s.<ref name=flow/>

The wall is composed of interstellar material interacting with the edge of the heliosphere. One paper released in 2013 studied the concept of a bow wave and hydrogen wall.<ref name=zank />
Another hypothesis suggests that the heliopause could be smaller on the side of the Solar System facing the Sun's orbital motion through the galaxy. It may also vary depending on the current velocity of the solar wind and the local density of the interstellar medium. It is known to lie far outside the orbit of [[Neptune]]. The current mission of the ''Voyager 1'' and ''[[Voyager 2|2]]'' spacecraft is to find and study the termination shock, heliosheath, and heliopause. Meanwhile, the [[Interstellar Boundary Explorer]] (IBEX) mission is attempting to image the heliopause from Earth orbit within two years of its 2008 launch. === Bow shock === {{further|Bow shocks in astrophysics}}
It was long hypothesized that the [[Sun]] produces a "shock wave" in its travels within the interstellar medium. It would occur if the interstellar medium is moving supersonically "toward" the Sun, since its solar wind moves "away" from the Sun supersonically. When the interstellar wind hits the heliosphere it slows and creates a region of turbulence. A bow shock was thought to possibly occur at about 230 AU,<ref name="apod-heliosphere" /> but in 2012 it was determined it probably does not exist.<ref name="No-Bow-Shock" /> This conclusion resulted from new measurements: The velocity of the LISM (Local Interstellar Medium) relative to the Sun's was previously measured to be 26.3 km/s by [[Ulysses (spacecraft)|Ulysses]], whereas IBEX measured it at 23.2 km/s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://astrobites.com/2012/05/14/no-shocks-for-this-bow-ibex-says-were-wrong/|title=No Shocks for This Bow: IBEX Says We're Wrong|date=14 May 2012|publisher=}}</ref>
This phenomenon has been observed outside the Solar System, around stars other than the Sun, by NASA's now retired orbital [[GALEX]] telescope. The red giant star [[Mira]] in the constellation [[Cetus]] has been shown to have both a debris tail of ejecta from the star and a distinct shock in the direction of its movement through space (at over 130 kilometers per second).
== Observational methods == [[Image:PioneerH2011.jpg|thumb|Pioneer H, on display at the National Air and Space Museum, was a canceled probe to study the Sun.<ref name="Pioneer-Swingby" />]]
=== Detection by spacecraft ===
The precise distance to, and shape of the heliopause is still uncertain. Interplanetary/interstellar [[spacecraft]] such as ''[[Pioneer 10]]'', ''[[Pioneer 11]]'', [[New Horizons]] and ''[[Voyager 2]]'' are traveling outward through the [[Solar System]] and will eventually pass through the heliopause. Contact to Pioneer 10 and 11 has been lost.
==== Cassini results ====
Rather than a comet-like shape, the heliosphere appears to be bubble-shaped according to data from [[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini's]] Ion and Neutral Camera (MIMI / INCA). Rather than being dominated by the collisions between the solar wind and the interstellar medium, the INCA ([[energetic neutral atom|ENA]]) maps suggest that the interaction is controlled more by particle pressure and magnetic field energy density.<ref name="Cassini-shape-solar-system" /><ref name="photojournal" />
==== IBEX results ==== [[File:IBEXmagneticfieldinfluence.jpg|thumb]]
Initial data from [[Interstellar Boundary Explorer]] (IBEX), launched in October 2008, revealed a previously unpredicted "very narrow ribbon that is two to three times brighter than anything else in the sky."<ref name="IBEX-2009" /> Initial interpretations suggest that "the interstellar environment has far more influence on structuring the heliosphere than anyone previously believed"<ref>Oct.15/09 IBEX team announcement at http://ibex.swri.edu/</ref> "No one knows what is creating the ENA (energetic neutral atoms) ribbon, ..."<ref name="Kerr-2009" />
"The IBEX results are truly remarkable! What we are seeing in these maps does not match with any of the previous theoretical models of this region. It will be exciting for scientists to review these ([[energetic neutral atom|ENA]]) maps and revise the way we understand our heliosphere and how it interacts with the galaxy."<ref>Dave McComas, IBEX Principal Investigator at http://ibex.swri.edu/</ref> In October 2010, significant changes were detected in the ribbon after 6 months, based on the second set of IBEX observations.<ref name=change>{{cite web|url=http://www.astrobio.net/pressrelease/3634/the-ever-changing-edge-of-the-solar-system|title=Complete Archive for Astrobiology Press Release, News Exclusive, News Briefs|publisher=|date=2010-10-02}}</ref> IBEX data did not support the existence of a bow shock,<ref name="No-Bow-Shock" /> but there might be a 'bow wave' according to one study.<ref name=zank/>
=== Locally === [[File:Evolving Heliophysics System Observatory.jpg|thumb|Overview of [[Heliophysics]] spacecraft circa 2011]]
Of particular interest is the Earth's interaction with the heliosphere, but its extent and interaction with other bodies in the solar system have also been studied. Some examples of missions that have or continue to collect data related to the heliosphere include ''(see also [[List of heliophysics missions]])'': * [[Solar Anomalous and Magnetospheric Particle Explorer]] * [[Solar and Heliospheric Observatory]] * [[Solar Dynamics Observatory]] * [[STEREO]] * [[Ulysses (spacecraft)]] *[[Parker Solar Probe]]
During a total eclipse the high-temperature corona can be more readily observed from Earth solar observatories. During the Apollo program the Solar wind was measured on the Moon via the [[Solar Wind Composition Experiment]]. Some examples of Earth surface based Solar observatories include the [[McMath–Pierce solar telescope]] or the newer [[GREGOR Solar Telescope]], and the refurbished [[Big Bear Solar Observatory]]. {{mergeto|Commodity chemicals|discuss=Talk:High production volume chemicals#Merger proposal|date=April 2018}} '''High production volume chemicals''', also referred to as HPV chemicals, are produced or imported into the United States in quantities of 1 million pounds or 500 tons per year.<ref name=EPA /> In [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development#Member countries|OECD countries]], HPV chemicals are defined as being produced at levels greater than 1,000 metric tons per producer/importer per year in at least one member country/region.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 2004 OECD List of High Production Volume Chemicals Environment Directorate|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/55/38/33883530.pdf|publisher=OECD|accessdate=13 March 2014|pages=143|year=2004}}</ref> A list of HPV chemicals serves as an overall priority list, from which chemicals are selected to gather data for a [[screening Information Dataset|screening information dataset]] (SIDS), for testing and for initial [[hazard]] assessment.
==History==
===OECD countries including EU=== In 1987, member countries of the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] decided to investigate existing chemicals. In 1991, they agreed to begin by focusing on High production volume (HPV) chemicals, where production volume was used as a [[surrogate endpoint|surrogate]] for data on occupational, consumer, and [[environmental exposure]].<ref>(OECD Council Acts, 1991).</ref> Each country agreed to "sponsor" the assessment of a proportion of the HPV chemicals. Countries also agreed on a minimum set of required information, the [[Screening Information Dataset|screening information dataset]] (SIDS). Six tests are: [[acute toxicity]], [[chronic toxicity]], [[developmental toxicity]]/[[reproductive toxicity]], [[mutagenicity]], [[ecotoxicity]] and environmental fate. Using SIDS and detailed exposure data OECD's [[High Production Volume Chemicals Programme]] conducted initial [[risk assessment]]s to screen and to identify any need for further work.
During the late 1990s, OECD member countries began to assess chemical categories and to use [[quantitative structure–activity relationship]] (QSAR) results to create OECD guidance documents, as well as a computerized QSAR toolbox.<ref>{{cite web|title=History: From the HPV Chemicals Programme to the Cooperative Chemicals Assessment Programme|url=http://www.oecd.org/chemicalsafety/risk-assessment/historyfromthehpvchemicalsprogrammetothecooperativechemicalsassessmentprogramme.htm| work=Chemical safety and biosafety; Assessment of chemicals|publisher=OECD|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> In 1998, the global [[chemical industry]], organized in the [[International Council of Chemical Associations]] (ICCA) initiative, offered to join OECD efforts. The ICCA promised to sponsor by 2013 about 1,000 substances from the OECD's HPV chemicals list "to establish as priorities for investigation", based on "presumed wide dispersive use, production in two or more global regions or similarity to another chemical, which met either of these criteria". OECD in turn agreed to refocus and to "increase transparency, efficiency and productivity and allow longer-term planning for governments and industry". The OECD refocus was on initial [[hazard]] assessments of HPV chemicals only, and no longer extensive [[exposure assessment|exposure information]] gathering and evaluation. Detailed exposure assessments within national (or regional) programmes and priority setting activities were postponed as post-SIDS work.
===United States=== On October 9, 1998, [[EPA Administrator]] Carol Browner sent letters to the CEOs of more than 900 chemical companies that manufacture HPV chemicals, asking them to participate in EPA's voluntary testing initiative, the so-called "HPV Challenge Program". The [[Environmental Defense Fund]], the [[American Petroleum Institute]], and [[American Chemistry Council]] joined in the effort.<ref>{{cite web|title=High Production Volume (HPV) Challenge|url=http://www.epa.gov/chemrtk/pubs/general/basicinfo.htm#creation|work=Chemical Safety and Pollution Prevention Pollution Prevention & Toxics|publisher=EPA| accessdate=13 March 2014|date=12 June 2012}}</ref>
== HPV chemical lists== The OECD list of HPV chemicals keeps changing. A 2004 list of 143 pages contained 4,842 entries.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 2004 OECD List of High Production Volume Chemicals|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/55/38/33883530.pdf|publisher=OECD|accessdate=13 March 2014|year=2004}}</ref> A 2007 list was published in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 2007 OECD List of High Production Volume Chemicals|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/32/9/43947965.pdf|publisher=OECD|accessdate=13 March 2014|year=2009}}</ref>
{{As of| 2009}} the EPA's HPV list had 2,539 chemicals, while the HPV Challenge Program chemical list contained only 1,973 chemicals because inorganic chemicals and polymers were not included.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=U.S. EPA (Environmental Protection Agency)|title=The HPV Voluntary Challenge Chemical List|url= http://www.epa.gov/hpv/pubs/update/hpvchmlt.htm|date=1990}}</ref>
The EPA has published an online list of HPV chemicals since 2010. The list is not numerated and without footnotes.<ref name=EPA>{{cite web|title=HPV Chemical Hazard Characterizations|url=http://iaspub.epa.gov/oppthpv/hpv_hc_characterization.get_report?doctype=2|work=High Production Volume Information System (HPVIS)|publisher=US EPA|accessdate=13 March 2014|date=March 13, 2014}}</ref>
==Regulatory context==
===Europe=== The "Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Management" ([[SAICM]]) is a policy for achieving safe production and use of chemicals worldwide by 2020, developed with stakeholders from more than 140 countries, signed by 100 governments, adopted by the [[UNEP]] Governing Council in February 2006. The [[Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals]] (REACH) proposal and the [[European Chemicals Agency]] will help the EU to fulfill objectives of SAICM.<ref>{{cite web|title=Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH), establishing a European Chemicals Agency and amending Directive 1999/45/EC and Regulation (EC) on Persistent Organic Pollutants|url=http://register.consilium.europa.eu/pdf/en/06/st15/st15315.en06.pdf|publisher=European Union|accessdate=14 March 2014|author=Council of the European Union|pages=756|date=14 December 2006}}</ref>
The [[Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants]] has aimed to control production, use, trade, disposal and release of twelve [[Persistent organic pollutants]] (POPs); the European Community has proposed five additional chemicals. The Convention bans deliberate production and use of POPs, bans the development of new POPs, and aims at minimizing releases of unintentionally produced POPs. The Convention has so far been ratified by the European Community, 18 member states and the two accession countries.
===United States=== The 1976 [[Toxic Substances Control Act]] requires the EPA to "compile, keep current, and publish a list of each chemical substance that is manufactured or processed in the United States". In 1998, the EPA reported the most heavily used HPV chemicals in commerce were largely untested: 43% of 2,800 HPV chemicals had no basic [[toxicity test|toxicity data]] or screening level data at all, 50% had incomplete screening data, and only 7% of the HPV chemicals had a complete set of screening level toxicity data. However, screening level data, even if they indicated a problem, were not sufficient to restrict the use of a compound.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/hpv/pubs/general/hazchem.pdf|publisher=Environmental Protection Agency|date=April 1998|title= Chemical Hazard Data Availability Study. What do we really know about the safety of high production volume chemicals? |author= Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics|pages=35}}</ref> In 1986, 2003, 2005, and in 2011 EPA issued regulations to amend and update the TSCA inventory.
As of April 2010, about 84,000 chemicals were on the TSCA inventory, per a [[GAO]] report.<ref name=GAO>{{cite web|title=TSCA Inventory Reset|url=http://www.epa.gov/champ/pubs/hpv/tsca.html|work=Chemical Assessment and Management Program (ChAMP)|publisher=EPA|accessdate=13 March 2014|date=April 29, 2010}}</ref> TSCA Section 4 gives EPA the authority to demand chemical testing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chemical Regulation: Observations on the Toxic Substances Control Act and EPA Implementation|url=http://www.gao.gov/assets/660/655209.txt|work=GAO-13-696T|publisher=GAO|accessdate=13 March 2014|date=June 13, 2013}}</ref>
==Toxicity data== In 1982, U.S. manufacturers, processors, and importers of 75 chemicals that the [[International Agency for Research on Cancer]] had found to cause cancers in animals, but the carcinogenicity of which in humans was uncertain, were surveyed. Only for 13 of the 75 chemicals had epidemiologic studies on human health been completed or were in progress. Eighteen of the 75 were HPV chemicals and only for eight HPV chemicals had epidemiologic studies been completed or were in progress. The largest number of chemicals (19) were drugs, and none of them had been epidemiologically studied. Seven chemicals that had been studied were used as pesticides.<ref>{{cite journal| title=Availability of epidemiologic data on humans exposed to animal carcinogens. II. Chemical uses and production volume|journal=Teratognesise Carcinogenesis Mutagenesis|year=1982| volume=2| issue=2|pages=151–67|pmid=6126936|author=Karstadt M |author2=Bobal R.| doi=10.1002/tcm.1770020205}}</ref>
In 1997 the [[Environmental Defense Fund]] reported in “Toxic Ignorance” results of its analysis of the availability of basic health test data on HPV chemicals that only 29% of the HPV chemicals in the US met minimum data requirements.<ref>{{cite web|title=Toxic Ignorance.|url=https://duckduckgo.com/l/?kh=-1&uddg=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.edf.org%2Fhealth%2Freports%2Ftoxic-ignorance|publisher=Environmental Defense Fund.|accessdate=25 February 2015|date=Summer 1997}}</ref> In 1998 the EPA published a report CHEMICAL HAZARD DATA AVAILABILITY STUDY showing "55% of TRI chemicals have had full SIDS testing, while only 7% of other chemicals have full test data".<ref>{{cite book|author1=EPA’s Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics|title=Chemical Hazard Data Availability Study: What Do We Really Know About the Safety of High Production Volume Chemicals?|publisher=EPA|pages=35|date=April 1998}}</ref> They wrote "...of the 830 companies making HPV chemicals in the US, 148 companies have NO SIDS data available on their chemicals; an additional 459 companies sell products for which, on average, half or less of SIDS tests are available. Only 21 companies (or 3% of the 830 companies) have all SIDS tests available for their chemicals. The basic set of test data costs about $200,000 per chemical." In 1999, the European Union (EU) published a study about how many EU-HPV chemicals were [[Publicly Available Specification|publicly available]] in a comprehensive chemical data base called [[IUCLID]]: Only 14% of the EU-HPV chemicals had data at the level of the base-set, 65% had less than base-set, and 21% had no data available. The authors concluded, "more data [were] publicly available than most previous studies" had shown.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=R Allanou |author2=BG Hansen |author3=Y van der Bilt |title=Public Availability of Data on EU High Production Volume Chemicals|journal=EUR| year=1999| issue=18996| publisher=European Union|url=http://www.chemicalspolicy.org/downloads/DataAvailabilityEUHPV.pdf}}</ref>
In 2004, one of the partners in EPA's HPV Challenge Program assessed 532 up to then unsponsored chemicals, whether they were "orphaned" or not, and found: * 156 chemicals (29%) likely were still "orphans" – i.e., they could and should be sponsored, but had not been * 103 chemicals (19%) had an unclear status * 266 chemicals (50%) were likely no longer HPV * only 7 chemicals (1%) appeared to be in the process of becoming sponsored.<ref name=ED>{{cite web|title=Orphan Chemicals in the HPV Challenge: A Status Report|url=http://www.environmentaldefense.org.|publisher=Environmental Defense|accessdate=14 March 2014|author1=Richard A. Denison |page=12|date=June 2004}}</ref> Since 2009, the EPA required companies to perform toxicity testing on merely 34 chemicals. In 2011, the EPA announced, but as of 2013 had yet to finalize, plans to require testing for 23 additional chemicals, so altogether 57 chemicals. The EPA has prioritized 83 chemicals for [[risk assessment]], and initiated seven assessments in 2012, with plans to start 18 additional assessments in 2013 and 2014.<ref name=GAO /> In 2007, EPA began Toxcast which uses "automated chemical screening technologies (called "high-throughput screening assays") to expose living cells or isolated proteins to chemicals".<ref>{{cite web|title=ToxCast™ Advancing the next generation of chemical safety evaluation|url=http://www.epa.gov/ncct/toxcast/|publisher=EPA|accessdate=25 February 2015|date=2009}}</ref>, <ref>{{cite journal| title=ToxCast Chemical Landscape: Paving the Road to 21st Century Toxicology|journal=Chemical Research in Toxicology|year=2016| volume=29| issue=8|pages=1225–1251|pmid=27367298|author=Richard A |author2=Judson R.| doi=10.1021/acs.chemrestox.6b00135}}</ref>
In 2009, EPA reported that it developed a system called ACToR (Aggregated Computational Toxicology Resource) to expose living cells or isolated proteins to chemicals. It pooled chemical research, data and screening tools from multiple federal agencies including the National Toxicology Program/ National Institute of Environmental Health Science, National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences and the Food and Drug Administration.

'''Hydrodenitrogenation''' ('''HDN''') is an industrial process for the removal of nitrogen from [[petroleum]]. Organonitrogen compounds, even though they occur at low levels, are undesirable because they cause poisoning of downstream catalysts. Furthermore, upon combustion, organonitrogen compounds generate [[NOx]], a pollutant. HDN is effected as general hydroprocessing, which traditionally focuses on [[hydrodesulfurization]] (HDS) because sulfur compounds are even more problematic. To some extent, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is also effected.<ref>Topsøe, H.; Clausen, B. S.; Massoth, F. E., Hydrotreating Catalysis, Science and Technology, Springer-Verlag: Berlin, 1996.</ref>
Typical organonitrogen compounds in petroleum include [[quinoline]]s and [[porphyrin]]s and their derivatives. The total nitrogen content is typically less than 1% and the targeted levels are in the ppm range. As described in [[organic geochemistry]], organonitrogen compounds are derivatives or degradation products of the compounds in the living matter that comprised the precursor to fossil fuels. In HDN, the organonitrogen compounds are treated at high temperatures with [[hydrogen]] in the presence of a [[catalyst]], the net transformation being:<ref>Prins, Roel "Hydrotreating" Edited by Ertl, Gerhard From Handbook of Heterogeneous Catalysis (2nd Edition) (2008), 6, 2695-2718. {{ISBN|978-3-527-31241-2}}</ref> :R<sub>3</sub>N + 3 H<sub>2</sub> → 3 RH + NH<sub>3</sub>
The catalysts generally consist of [[cobalt]] and [[nickel]] as well as [[molybdenum disulfide]] or less often [[tungsten disulfide]] [[catalyst support|supported]] on alumina]]. The precise composition of the catalyst, i.e. Co/Ni and Mo/W ratios, are tuned for particular feedstocks. A wide variety of catalyst compositions have been considered, including metal [[phosphide]]s.<ref>Oyama, S. Ted; Gott, Travis; Zhao, Haiyan; Lee, Yong-Kul "Transition metal phosphide hydroprocessing catalysts: A review" Catalysis Today 2009, vol. 143, pp. 94-107. {{doi|10.1016/j.cattod.2008.09.019}}</ref>

'''Indian Salt Service''' is a [[Civil Services of India|Central Civil Service]] of the [[Government of India]]. Under the administrative control of the [[Ministry of Commerce and Industry (India)|Ministry of Commerce and Industry]], it is one of the smallest Central services under the Government of India.
== History == The organized and uniform collection of tax revenue on [[Table salt|salt]] in British India began under the [[British Raj]]. Both before and after that, various native rulers of the Indian [[Princely states]] (outside British India proper) collected such revenue in accordance with their own revenue and administrative requirements and resources. In 1856, the government appointed the young [[William Chichele Plowden]], Secretary of the Board of Revenue of the [[North West Provinces]], to report on the establishment of a uniform system of revenue realisation from salt within the British Provinces, and he recommended the extension of the [[Excise tax|excise]] system, the reduction of duty, and the introduction of a system of [[licensing]] as the measures to achieve this goal.<ref name="saltcomindia">{{cite web|title=SALT ADMINISTRATION (PAST AND PRESENT)|url=http://saltcomindia.gov.in/HistoryOfSalt.html?tp=html|publisher=Office of Salt Commissioner, DIPP|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>
In 1876, separate departments under a Salt Commissioner were set up, and these operated at the level of each [[Presidencies and provinces of British India|British Province and Presidency]]. It was with the passing of the [[Government of India Act, 1935]], that within British India (which then included much of present-day [[Pakistan]]) salt came under the exclusive control of the central government, with the Government of India taking over the task of collecting salt revenue and transferring it from the provincial salt agencies to the Central Excise and Revenue Department.<ref name="saltcomindia" /> In 1944, the Government of India passed the Central Excises and Salt Act which unified and amended all laws dealing with duties on excise and salt. In the 1940s and 1950s, after Independence, the Princely States were integrated into the new [[Union of India]], so that for the first time this service was extended to all of them.{{cn|date = May 2013}}
The Salt Department was originally a part of the Central Board of Revenue under the [[Ministry of Finance (India)|Ministry of Finance]], but since a reorganisation of the ministries of India in 1957 it has come under the authority of the [[Ministry of Commerce and Industry (India)|Ministry of Commerce and Industry]].<ref name="saltcomindia" />
According to the [[Union list in India|Union List]] of subjects under the [[Schedule VII|Seventh Schedule]] of the [[Indian Constitution]], the "manufacture, supply and distribution of salt by Union agencies; regulation and control of manufacture, supply and distribution of salt by other agencies", is the responsibility of the Government of India.<ref>{{cite web|title=SEVENTH SCHEDULE: List I—Union List|url=http://lawmin.nic.in/olwing/coi/coi-english/Const.Pock%202Pg.Rom8Fsss(35).pdf|publisher=Ministry of Law, Government of India|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref> The posts of Salt Controller, Deputy Salt Controller and Assistant Salt Controller were re-categorized as Salt Commissioner, Deputy Salt Commissioner and Assistant Salt Commissioner in 1952 and the Indian Salt Services were created in 1954 for the realisation of the entry under the Union List.<ref name="saltcomindia" /> The Salt Service has both Group A and Group B wings<!--what does this mean?-->.<ref>{{cite web|title=Part I - Central Civil Services, Group 'A'|url=http://www.persmin.gov.in/DOPT/EmployeesCorner/Acts_Rules/ccs(cca)/SCHEDULE-1.PDF|publisher=Ministry of Personnel, Government of India|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PART II - Central Civil Services, Group 'B'|url=http://www.persmin.gov.in/DOPT/EmployeesCorner/Acts_Rules/ccs(cca)/SCHEDULE-2.PDF|publisher=Ministry of Personnel, Government of India|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>
== Recruitment == The Salt Service is one of the smallest services under the Government of India with a sanctioned strength of only 11 posts.<ref>{{cite book|last=Maheshwari|first=S R|title=Indian Administration (Sixth Edition)|year=2004|publisher=Orient Longman|location=New Delhi|page=322|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E_Qu6ePC40kC&pg=PA322&lpg=PA322&dq=%22indian+salt+service%22#v=onepage&q=%22indian%20salt%20service%22&f=false|isbn=9788125019886}}</ref> As a central civil service, recruitment to the Indian Salt Service is conducted by the [[Union Public Service Commission]].
== Service hierarchy == The Indian Salt Service is part of India's Salt Organization which is headquartered in [[Jaipur]]. The service is headed by the Salt Commissioner below whom are five Deputy Salt Commissioners and nine Assistant Salt Commissioners who man the agency with the help of other supporting staff. The Deputy Salt Commissioners head regional offices and the Assistant Salt Commissioners are in charge of divisional offices of the organisation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asst. Salt Commissioner vs. The Secretary, Dept. of Industrial Policy & Promotions|url=http://www.indiankanoon.org/doc/8623711/?type=print|publisher=Indian Kanoon|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref> The Service has four regional offices at [[Chennai]], [[Mumbai]], [[Ahmedabad]] and [[Kolkata]] and field offices in the salt producing states.<ref name="dipp">{{cite web|title=Office of the Salt Commissioner|url=http://dipp.nic.in/English/AboutUs/Subordinate_Offices/Salt_Commissioner.aspx|publisher=Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion, Government of India|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>
== Functions == The Salt Service is tasked with several functions including monitoring and quality updation of salt, setting production targets, providing technical guidance to salt manufacturers and leasing and managing department lands for the same, collection of cess, fees and rents and the implementation of various schemes aimed at combating [[iodine deficiency]] and programs for promoting the growth of the salt industry in India.<ref name="dipp" /><ref>{{cite book|title=Report of the Fifth Central Pay Commission, Volume 2|year=1997|publisher=Government of India, Ministry of Finance|location=New Delhi|page=1213|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_I4OAQAAMAAJ&q=%22indian+salt+service%22&dq=%22indian+salt+service%22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Indian Salt Service|url=http://rozgarpatrika.com/civil-services/indian-salt-services|publisher=Rozgar Patrika|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} [[File:Building straight up.jpg|thumb|KEVA Planks Tower]] '''KEVA Planks''' are cuboid wooden [[Block (toy)|block toy]]s for children and adults. Each block is sized approximately 1/4 inch (6.35 mm) x 3/4 inch (19.05 mm) x 4 1/2 inches (114.3 mm). The blocks are available for sale in [[Maple (wood)|maple]], that is produced in the United States, and less expensive imported [[pine]] versions.<ref>{{cite web|title=KEVA planks Products|url=http://www.kevaplanks.com/page3/page3.html|accessdate=27 December 2013}}</ref>
KEVA Planks started out as a simple construction set that is unusual because they only use one piece and no connectors in glue, in contrast to other building sets that often have specific instructions and require sorting. It has developed into a teaching tool used in classrooms and enjoyed in homes.
A number of museums have KEVA exhibits for hands on experience with design and construction including: * [[Da Vinci Science Center]] of Allentown, PA<ref>{{cite web|title=Da Vinci Science Center KEVA Exhibit|url=http://www.davincisciencecenter.org/experiences/standard-exhibits/what-works-exhibit-area/keva-build-it-up/|accessdate=30 December 2013}}</ref> * [[Exploration Place]] of The Sedgwick County Science and Discovery Center of Wichita, Kansas<ref>{{cite web|title=Exploration Place KEVA Exhibit|url=http://www.exploration.org/keva.html|accessdate=30 December 2013}}</ref> * [[Lawrence Hall of Science]] at University of California, Berkeley, CA<ref>{{cite web|title=Design, Build, Test | Lawrence Hall of Science|url=http://www.lawrencehallofscience.org/visit/exhibits/design_build_test|accessdate=26 January 2015}}</ref> * [[Rochester Museum and Science Center]] in Rochester, NY<ref>{{cite web|title=Rochester Museum and Science Center KEVA exhibit|url=http://www.rmsc.org/MuseumAndScienceCenter/exhibits/KEVA/|accessdate=30 December 2013}}</ref> * [[Science World at Telus World of Science]] in Vancouver, BC<ref>{{cite web|title=Science World KEVA|url=http://www.scienceworld.ca/keva|accessdate=30 December 2013}}</ref> * [[SciWorks]] of Winston-Salem, NC<ref>{{cite web|title=SciWorks KEVA Exhibit|url=http://www.sciworks.org/visit/exhibits/kevaworks/|accessdate=30 December 2013}}</ref> * Kalamazoo [[Air Zoo]] of Kalamazoo, MI<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.airzoo.org/page.php?menu_id=30|title=Exhibits & Experiences {{!}} Air Zoo Aviation Museum & Science Education Center of Kalamazoo, Michigan|website=www.airzoo.org|language=en|access-date=2017-05-29}}</ref>
The tallest tower built with KEVA planks was 51 feet, 8 inches constructed at the [[National Building Museum]] in 2006.<ref name=FAQ>{{cite web|url=http://www.kevaplanks.com/page4/page40/page40.html |title=KEVA FAQ |publisher=kevaplanks.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref>
KEVA planks is a company located in [[Virginia]] now owned by Mindware division of Oriental Trading subsidiary of [[Berkshire Hathaway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kevaplanks.com/page41/page8/page8.html |title=KEVA planks Company|publisher=kevaplanks.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref>
== KEVA Planks in Educational Settings == KEVA Planks are used in schools, libraries, museums, and maker spaces. They are a teaching tool that can be used as a manipulative to teach subjects including math, science, geography, history, and humanities. They were featured at Destination Imagination Global Finals in Knoxville, TN in 2011.<ref>{{Citation|last=Destination Imagination|title=Keva Planks at Destination Imagination Global Finals 2011|date=2011-05-27|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAwveJUMFnI|accessdate=2017-03-07}}</ref>
Beginning in 2015, KEVA Planks traveled with [http://sharefairnation.org/ Share Fair Nation] STEMosphere events and was one of the most popular sessions in the professional development workshops.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ctd.northwestern.edu/chicagoevanston-share-fair-nation-2015|title=Chicago/Evanston Share Fair Nation 2015 {{!}} Northwestern Center for Talent Development|website=www.ctd.northwestern.edu|access-date=2017-03-07}}</ref> STEMosphere highlights innovative and creative teaching tools.
KEVA Planks were named number 3 in Worlds of Learning's Top Ten Makerspace Favorites of 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://worlds-of-learning.com/2016/11/29/top-ten-makerspace-favorites-2016/|title=Top Ten Makerspace Favorites of 2016|date=2016-11-29|website=Worlds of Learning|access-date=2017-03-07}}</ref>
They have been used as "de-stressors" at libraries at Duke University and the University of Virginia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kevaplanks.com/college/|title=College|website=KEVA planks|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-07}}</ref>

The '''Karrick process''' is a low-temperature [[carbonization]] (LTC) and [[pyrolysis]] process of carbonaceous materials. Although primarily meant for [[coal]] [[carbonization]], it also could be used for processing of [[oil shale]], [[lignite]] or any carbonaceous materials. These are heated at {{convert|450|°C|°F|abbr=on|-2}} to {{convert|700|°C|°F|abbr=on|-2}} in the absence of air to [[distillation|distill]] out [[synthetic fuel]]s–[[unconventional oil]] and [[syngas]]. It could be used for a [[coal liquefaction]] as also for a [[semi-coke]] production. The process was the work of oil shale technologist [[Lewis Karrick|Lewis Cass Karrick]] at the [[United States Bureau of Mines]] in the 1920s.
==History== The Karrick process was invented by Lewis Cass Karrick in the 1920s. Although Karrick did not invent coal LTC as such, he perfected the existing technologies resulting the Karrick process.<ref name=maynard> {{Cite book | last = Maynard | first = Elliot | title = Transforming the Global Biosphere | publisher = Watchmaker Publishing | page = 109 | year = 2000 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=AXkjj2lvlu0C&pg=PA109 | isbn = 978-0-9721713-1-1 | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} </ref> The retort used for the Karrick process based on the [[Nevada–Texas–Utah Retort]], used for the [[shale oil extraction]].<ref name=harris/>
In 1935, a Karrick LTC pilot plant was constructed in the coal research laboratory at the [[University of Utah]].<ref name=striner/> Commercial-size processing plants were operated during the 1930s in [[Colorado]], [[Utah]] and [[Ohio]]. During World War II, similar processing plant was operated by the [[United States Navy]].<ref name=striner> {{Cite book | last = Striner | first = Herbert E. | title = An analysis of the bituminous coal industry in terms of total energy supply and a synthetic oil program | publisher = Ayer Publishing | pages = 201–206 | year = 1979 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=AV16jNj_-oUC&pg=PA201&dq=Karrick+process | isbn = 978-0-405-12016-9 | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} </ref> In Australia, during World War II the Karrick process plants were used for [[shale oil]] extraction in New South Wales. In 1950s–1970s, the technology was used by the Rexco Company in its Snibston plant at [[Coalville]] in [[Leicestershire]], England.<ref name=harris> {{Cite paper |last = Harris |first = Alan |title = The impact of an emissions trading scheme on the fuel and energy industry. Submission to the Senate Enquiry on Fuel and Energy |publisher = Senate. Parliament of Australia |pages = 2; 7; 10–12 |date = 2008-08-29 |url = http://www.aph.gov.au/Senate/Committee/fuelenergy_ctte/submissions/sub0039.pdf |format = PDF |accessdate = 2009-07-04 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091002045506/http://web.senate@aph.gov.au/Senate/committee/fuelenergy_ctte/submissions/sub0039.pdf |archivedate = 2009-10-02 |df = }} </ref>
==Process== The Karrick process is a low-temperature [[carbonization]] process, which uses a hermetic retort.<ref name=handbook2/> For commercial scale production, a retort about {{convert|3|ft|m}} in diameter and {{convert|20|ft|m}} high would be used. The process of carbonization would last about 3 hours.<ref name=larsen> {{Cite book | last1 = Larsen | first1 = William A. | last2 = Stutz | first2 = Clifford N. | title = Design of Plant for Low Temperature Carbonization of Utah Coal by Karrick Process | publisher = [[University of Utah]] | date = 1932-05-14}} </ref>
Superheated steam is injected continuously into the top of a retort filled by coal. At first, in contact with cool coal, the steam condenses to water acting as a cleaning agent. While temperature of coal rises, the [[destructive distillation]] starts.<ref name=striner/> Coal is heated at {{convert|450|°C|°F|abbr=on|-2}} to {{convert|700|°C|°F|abbr=on|-2}} in the absence of air. The carbonization temperature is lower compared with {{convert|800|°C|°F|abbr=on|-2}} to {{convert|1000|°C|°F|abbr=on|-2}} for producing metallurgic coke. The lower temperature optimizes the production of [[coal tar]]s richer in lighter hydrocarbons than normal coal tar, and therefore it is suitable for processing into fuels.<ref name=handbook2> {{Cite book | last =Speight | first = James G. | title = Synthetic Fuels Handbook: Properties, Process, and Performance | publisher = [[McGraw-Hill|McGraw-Hill Professional]] | pages = 9; 25 | year = 2008 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=E3pgqnGgHjIC&pg=PA9 | isbn = 978-0-07-149023-8 | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} </ref> Resulting water, oil and coal tar, and syngas moves out from retort through outlet [[valve]]s at the bottom of the retort. The residue ([[char]] or semi-coke) remains in the retort.<ref name=striner/> While the produced liquids are mostly a by-product, the semi-coke is the main product, a solid and smokeless fuel.<ref name=hook> {{cite journal |title=A review on coal to liquid fuels and its coal consumption |last=Höök |first=Mikael |last2=Aleklett |first2=Kjell |journal=[[International Journal of Energy Research]] |volume=33 |issue= |year=2009 |publisher=Wiley InterScience |url=http://www.tsl.uu.se/uhdsg/Publications/CTL_Article.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-07-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nhxlQsjX?url=http://www.tsl.uu.se/uhdsg/Publications/CTL_Article.pdf |archivedate=2010-02-21 |df= }} </ref>
The Karrick LTC process generates no [[carbon dioxide]], but it does produce a significant amount of [[carbon monoxide]].
==Products== In the Karrick process, 1 [[short ton]] of coal yields up to 1 [[Barrel (volume)|barrel]] of oils and coal tars (12% by weight), and produces {{convert|3000|cuft|m3}} of rich [[coal gas]] and {{convert|1500|lb|kg}} of solid smokeless [[char]] or semi-coke (for one [[metric ton]], 0.175 m³ of oils and coal tars, 95 m³ of gas, and 750 kg of semi-coke).<ref name=striner/><ref name=handbook2/> Yields by volume of approximately 25% [[gasoline]], 10% [[kerosene]] and 20% good quality [[fuel oil]] are obtainable from coal.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} Gasoline obtained from coal by the Karrick process combined with cracking and refining is equal in quality to [[tetraethyl lead]] gasolines.<ref name=striner/><ref name=stewart> {{Cite paper |last = Stewart |first = Danny |title = The role of alternative fuels. Submission to the Senate Enquiry on Fuel and Energy |publisher = Senate. Parliament of Australia |page = 29 |year = 2008 |url = http://www.aph.gov.au/SEnate/committee/fuelenergy_ctte/submissions/sub0028.pdf |format = PDF |accessdate = 2009-07-04 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091002042138/http://web.senate@aph.gov.au/Senate/committee/fuelenergy_ctte/submissions/sub0028.pdf |archivedate = 2009-10-02 |df = }} </ref> More power is developed in internal combustion engines and an increase in fuel economy of approximately 20% is obtainable under identical operating conditions.<ref name=harris/>
Semi-coke can be used for utility boilers and coking coal in steel smelters, yields more heat than raw coal and can be converted to [[water gas]]. Water gas can be converted to oil by the [[Fischer-Tropsch process]].<ref name=handbook2/> [[Coal gas]] from Karrick LTC yields greater [[energy density|energy content]] than [[natural gas]]. [[Phenol]]ic wastes are used by the chemical industry as feedstock for plastics, etc. Electrical power can be cogenerated at nominal equipment cost.<ref name=harris/>
==Economic viability== Oils, including petroleum, have long been extracted from coal. Production plants were merely shut down in the 1880s because crude oil became cheaper than coal liquefaction. The capability itself, however, has never disappeared. Eight years of pilot plant tests by Karrick attest that states, cities or even smaller towns, could make their own gas and generate their own electricity.<ref name=striner/>
A 30-ton plant and oil refinery will show a profit over and above all operating and capital costs and the products will sell at attractive prices for equivalent products. The private sector should require no subsidies, but not in competition with those who skim off the oil from coal and sell the residual smokeless fuel to power plants.<ref name=harris/>
The cheapest liquid fuel from coal will come when processed by LTC for both liquid fuels and electric power. As a tertiary product of the coal distilling process, electrical energy can be generated at a minimum equipment cost. A Karrick LTC plant with 1 kiloton of daily coal capacity produces sufficient steam to generate 100,000 [[kilowatt hour]]s of electrical power at no extra cost excepting capital investment for electrical equipment and loss of steam temperature passing through turbines.<ref name=harris/> The process steam cost could be low since this steam could be derived from off-peak boiler capacity or from turbines in central electric stations. Fuel for steam and superheating would subsequently be reduced in cost.<ref name=harris/>
==Advantages and disadvantages== Compared to the [[Bergius process]], the Karrick process is cheaper, requires less water and destroys less the thermal value (one-half that of the Bergius process).<ref name=harris/> The smokeless semi-coke fuel, when burned in an open grate or in boilers, delivers 20% to 25% more heat than raw coal.<ref name=striner/> The coal gas should deliver more heat than natural gas per heat unit contained due to the greater quantity of combined carbon and lower dilution of the combustion gases with water vapor.<ref name=harris/>
